block.p: Behind Painting Sold Online Was a Partly False Story The man who sold a painting on the Internet for $135,805 acknowledged that he concocted part of the story he used to describe the work, which bore the initials ''R.D.,'' creating speculation that it was painted by the California artist Richard Diebenkorn.

Far from being a married homeowner who cleaned the painting out of his garage, the man is a single lawyer who has sold paintings on eBay before. But he said that he did not fake the painting or add the signature and that he would cancel the sale if experts determine that the canvas is not by Diebenkorn. [Page A1.]

Striving to Make Copyrights Moot While courts struggle over the recording industry's challenge to digital music-swapping, software is being written that could make it impossible to control the traffic in any kind of digital information -- whether it is music, video, text or software. [A1.]

Bestfoods Hints Deal Is Possible When Bestfoods rejected a takeover offer from Unilever last week, it seemed emphatic. But over the last few days, senior executives at Bestfoods have talked with the company's largest investors, discussing their reasons for turning down the $18.4 billion offer, saying that Unilever has underestimated the savings of such a deal. The executives' position hints that Bestfoods would consider a merger at the right price, analysts said. Shares of Bestfoods fell $1, to $63.50. [C2.]

Profit and Revenue Rise at Cisco Cisco Systems said that its third-quarter profit beat expectations while it posted a 55 percent gain in sales as the leading supplier of hardware for the Internet. [C2.]

Stocks Slide on Rate Concerns Stocks dropped on fears about the effect of an expected increase in interest rates. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 84.37 points, or 2.3 percent, to 3,585.01. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 66.88 points, to 10,536.75, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 12.03 points, to 1,412.14. [C10.]

No Phone Offer Seen in Hong Kong Singapore Telecommunications probably will not make a rival bid for Hong Kong's flagship telephone company, Cable and Wireless HKT, executives close to the company said. They said Singapore Telecom was balking at the price it would have to pay. [C4.]

Janus to Close Three of Its Funds Under an onslaught of money from investors, the Janus mutual fund group said that it would close three funds: the $42 billion Janus Worldwide, the Janus Olympus Fund and the Janus Global Life Sciences Fund. [C2.]

Journey From Boredom to Bossdom As preparation for the executive suite, it may be hard to beat the combination of boredom and curiosity. Sunny Vanderbeck, the head of Data Return, which runs business software on the Web, recalls experiences that began as intense curiosity or efforts to relieve boredom. Probably nothing prepared him better for what he does now, he says, than training as an Airborne Ranger. The Boss. [C6.]
NTT DoCoMo to Buy Dutch Stake NTT DoCoMo, Japan's largest mobile phone company, agreed to acquire a 15 percent stake in the Dutch mobile phone operator KPN Mobile for about $4.5 billion. [C4.]

Coke in Deal With Lawyer's Channel Coca-Cola said that it was becoming a major advertiser on a cable channel owned by a Florida lawyer who represents four of the plaintiffs in a racial discrimination suit brought by the company's black employees. [C10.]

Th Psychological Toll of Traveling Research by the World Bank has shown that not only can extensive business travel take a physical toll, being on the road can also take a psychological toll on workers and their families. Joe Sharkey: Business Travel. [C8.]
